Furthermore, the Dharma body of the buddhas is profound, most profound. How can this profundity be seen?
Here there are many verses.
The commentary says:

As for the profundity of the Dharma body of the buddhas, it is said that the essence of this Dharma body is difficult to perceive, because even the perceptive wisdom of the wise in the world does not understand it.
As for the most profound, it is said that the distinctions of this Dharma body are difficult to perceive, because the perceptive wisdom of the Å›rÄvakas and others cannot comprehend it.
Such profundity will be briefly revealed in twelve verses.
The treatise says:
The buddhas have non-arising as arising, and also non-abiding as abiding,
All activities are effortless, and the fourth food is their food.
The commentary says:
This verse reveals the profundity of arising, abiding, and the abiding of activity.
The Buddha's birthlessness as birth means that the buddhas are born while not being born, which is called the profundity of birth.
Also, no abiding as abiding means that in samsara and nirvana there is no abiding as abiding. This is precisely the abiding in the nirvana of no abiding, which is called the profundity of abiding.
All activities without effort means that without effort one performs all activities, just like the world's maá¹‡i jewels and heavenly music, which is called the profundity of activity.
The fourth food as food means that there are four kinds of food:
The first is impure sustenance, which refers to those with all bonds, who by means of food such as morsels cause the body to abide.

The second is pure and impure sustenance, which refers to those born in the form and formless realms, who by means of the food of contact, intention, and consciousness abide, because they are already free from desire and thus have no morsel food.
Those on the path of stream-entry and so forth are still learners, and thus their sustenance is also pure and impure sustenance. Their own bodies abide by means of the four foods.
Third, the food of abiding in pure dependence, which is the four foods that enable the self-body of arhats and others to abide.
Fourth, the food of only manifesting dependence, which is the four foods such as morsels that the Buddha-World-Honored One manifests and uses.

When the TathÄgata eats, he does not actually receive food, nor does he rely on food for his own body to abide. However, in accordance with the world, he manifests receiving and using food, manifesting that his body abides by relying on food.
Because he manifests receiving the fourth food and abiding, it is called the profundity of abiding.
The treatise says:
Without difference and also immeasurable, without measure and one action,
Not solid action and solid action, all Buddhas possess the three bodies.
The commentary says:
This verse displays the profundity of establishment, number, and action.ğŸ”½Without difference shows the profundity of establishment, because it is established without distinction.
Also immeasurable shows the profundity of number, which shows that the establishment has immeasurable numbers.
As for the phrase incalculable and one action, although there are incalculable [actions], there is no separate action.
What is that?
One action transforms and uses action without distinction, because it accomplishes benefiting others.
As for the phrase non-firm action and firm action, the action of the essential body is firmly abiding, while the other two bodies' actions are not firmly abiding.
In this way, all are called the profundity of action.
The treatise states:
The manifestation of perfect enlightenment does not exist, yet all enlightenment is not non-existent.
In each moment, there are innumerable, existing and non-existing manifestations.
The commentary states:
This verse displays the profundity of the manifestation of perfect enlightenment.
The phrase the manifestation of perfect enlightenment does not exist means that in the dependent arising, the imagined nature does not exist.
The phrase yet all enlightenment is not non-existent means that in the dependent arising, the perfected nature truly exists.

The phrase in each moment, there are innumerable means that in the innumerable Ganges sands of worlds, moment by moment, simultaneously, there are innumerable Buddhas manifesting perfect enlightenment.
Existence is not existence means that all Tathagatas are existence and non-existence, because they are manifested by the nature of emptiness and attain the supreme position.
The treatise says:
Not defiled, not free from defilement, one attains liberation through desire.
Understanding desire and non-desire, one enters the true nature of desire.
The commentary says:
This verse shows the profundity of detachment from desire.
Why is it not defiled?
Because it cuts off the entanglements of greed.
It is not free from defilement because it does not quickly and permanently cut off the latent tendencies of greed.
One attains liberation through desire means that by retaining such latent tendencies of greed, one attains great enlightenment;
if one cuts off such latent tendencies of greed, one should quickly enter nirvana like the Shravakas and others.
Understanding desire and non-desire means understanding that the desire and greed that are imagined do not have the nature of desire.
Entering the true nature of desire means realizing and verifying the true suchness of the dharma of desire.
The treatise says:
The buddhas transcend all aggregates, yet abide within the aggregates.
They are neither the same as nor different from them, and are not abandoned but well tranquil.
The commentary explains:
This verse reveals the profundity of the abandonment of the aggregates.
The buddhas transcend all aggregates means that the tathÄgatas surpass all the collections of form and so forth that are imagined, because they truly see that what is imagined cannot be obtained.
They abide within the aggregates means that the buddhas abide within the aggregates of the nature of dharmas.

They are neither the same as nor different from them means that the aggregates of the nature of dharmas cannot be said to be different from those aggregates that are imagined, because the nature of what is imagined is originally non-existent;
they cannot be said to be the same, because what is imagined accords with defilement.
Dharmas and the nature of dharmas are neither the same nor different.
They are not abandoned but well tranquil means that they do not discard the aggregates of the nature of dharmas, because they are precisely the marvelous goodness of eternal quiescence.
The treatise states:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
The activities of all Buddhas are mixed together, just like the waters of the great ocean.
I have already done, am now doing, and will do benefiting others, without such thoughts.
The commentary explains:
This verse shows the profundity of maturation.

The activities of all Buddhas are mixed together means that all the activities of the Tathagatas to benefit and bring peace to sentient beings are mutually harmonious and combined into one flavor, indistinguishable.
Question:
How are these activities equal?
Answer:
Just like the waters of the great ocean.
It is like the great ocean, to which all rivers flow, the waters of the same flavor and indistinguishable, all equally benefiting fish and other creatures.

I have already done, am now doing, and will do benefiting others, without such thoughts means being free from the discriminating thoughts of benefiting others at the three times of past, present, and future, yet being able to spontaneously carry out benefiting others, like Indra and the wish-fulfilling jewel and heavenly music, which have no thoughts but still function.
The treatise states:
Sentient beings' faults do not manifest, like the moon in a broken vessel;
Pervading all worlds, by the light of the Dharma like the sun.
The commentary says:
This verse illustrates the profundity of manifestation.
Question:
If the TathÄgata's body is eternal, why does it not manifest at all times?
Answer:
Sentient beings' faults do not manifest, like the moon in a broken vessel.
Just as water cannot remain in a broken vessel and the moon's reflection does not appear, this is not the moon's fault, but the fault of the vessel.
The Buddha's reflection does not appear in sentient beings' bodies without the clear and moist water of samÄdhi, which is not the TathÄgata's fault, but the fault of sentient beings.
Water is used as a metaphor for the clear and moist nature of samÄdhi.

It is said that the TathÄgata is the true, wonderful, pure, and undefiled Dharma-shadow, which appears when there is a response. If there is no response, it is like the congenitally blind who cannot see.

By the light of the Dharma, like the sun, pervading all worlds means that the sun of the buddhas emits the light of the true teachings such as the sÅ«tras, universally illuminating the world of all beings, and those with affinity see it;
Those who do not see it are at fault themselves, not the TathÄgata.
It is like the sun in the world, its light universally illuminates, those with eyes see it, but the blind do not see it.
The treatise says:
Sometimes manifesting perfect enlightenment, sometimes nirvÄá¹‡a like a fire,
This is never non-existent, because the bodies of the buddhas are eternal.
The commentary says:
This verse shows the profundity of manifesting enlightenment and nirvÄá¹‡a.
Sometimes manifesting perfect enlightenment, sometimes nirvÄá¹‡a like a fire means that just as a fire in the world sometimes burns and sometimes goes out,
the buddhas are also like this. For those wholesome roots that are not yet mature, they manifest perfect enlightenment, enabling them to mature and quickly attain liberation;
For those who have already attained maturity in wholesome roots and have already attained liberation, they manifest parinirvÄá¹‡a because there is nothing more to be done.
The meaning of this has never been before and so on is easy to understand.
The treatise says:
The Buddha, in non-holy dharmas, the human realm and evil destinies,
In the dharmas of non-Brahmic conduct, abides in the supreme self-nature.
The commentary says:
This verse shows the profundity of abiding.

Abiding in the supreme self-nature in non-holy dharmas means that in unwholesomeness, by abiding in the supreme self-nature, one abides in the supreme, namely the abidings of emptiness, wishlessness, and signlessness, because one abides by taking unwholesome dharmas as objects.

Abiding in the supreme self-nature in the human realm and evil destinies means that in the human realm and all evil destinies, by abiding in the supreme self-nature, one abides in the supreme, namely the abidings of the meditative absorptions and the meditative equipoises, because one abides by taking those destinies as objects.

Abiding in the supreme essence of non-Brahmic practices means abiding in the supreme essence of non-Brahmic practices, abiding in the supreme, namely the four immeasurables, which are called the Brahma abodes, because they abide in non-Brahmic practices.
The treatise says:
The Buddha practices everywhere, yet he does not practice in any one place.
He manifests in all bodies, yet he is not within the scope of the six sense faculties.
The commentary says:
This verse shows the profundity of the essence.
As for the essence, it refers to the TathÄgata's eternal abiding in the Dharma realm and the virtues he has accomplished, which are collectively called the essence.
The Buddha practices everywhere means that his subsequent attainment wisdom pervades everywhere.
Where does it pervade?
It pervades the distinctions of good, bad, and neutral, contaminated and uncontaminated, conditioned and unconditioned, and so forth.
Yet he does not practice in any one place means that because non-discriminating wisdom is non-discriminating, it does not practice any differentiated objects.
Manifesting in all bodies means that the transformation body manifests birth in all places.
Not the domain of the six sense faculties means that the ultimate, eternally abiding Dharma body is not something that beings of the same class in such places as the hells can grasp.
The treatise says:
Afflictions are suppressed but not eliminated, like poison harmed by spells.
Leaving behind afflictions until they are exhausted, one realizes the omniscience of the Buddha.
The commentary says:
This verse reveals the profundity of eliminating afflictions.
Afflictions are suppressed but not eliminated means that in the bodhisattva stage, all afflictions are suppressed but not permanently eliminated.
Like poison harmed by spells is an analogy: just as various poisons are harmed by powerful spells, although their substance is not yet eliminated, they do not cause harm.
Afflictions are also like this. By the power of mindfulness and wisdom, the entanglements of present activity are suppressed, but the latent tendencies still remain.
Why do the latent tendencies of afflictions still remain?
Fearing that they would quickly attain parinirvÄá¹‡a like the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle, for this reason afflictions are the cause, and when afflictions are exhausted, one attains omniscience.
As a verse says:
Mindfulness and wisdom power control afflictions and realize bodhi,
Like poison held by a mantra, faults become merits.
The treatise says:
Afflictions become factors of enlightenment, and birth and death become nirvÄá¹‡a,
Endowed with great skillful means, the buddhas are inconceivable.
The commentary says:
This verse shows the inconceivable profundity.

Namely, afflictions are transformed into factors of enlightenment, and the suffering and distress of birth and death become nirvÄá¹‡a. Such cause and effect cannot be conceived of by worldly principles.
The treatise says:

It should be known that this so-called profound has twelve kinds, namely, the profundity of birth, abiding, action, abiding, establishment, number, action, supreme enlightenment, separation from desires, abandoning the aggregates, maturation, manifestation, demonstrating supreme enlightenment and nirvÄá¹‡a, abiding, revealing one's own body, severing afflictions, and inconceivable profundity.
The commentary says:
These twelve kinds are all difficult to understand, so they are called profound.
The individual characteristics of each have already been explained above.
The treatise states:
If bodhisattvas contemplate the Dharma body of the Buddha, by how many kinds of thoughts should they cultivate this contemplation?
In brief, bodhisattvas contemplate the Dharma body of the Buddha by seven kinds of thoughts, and they should cultivate this contemplation.
First, the buddhas attain mastery over all dharmas, and one should cultivate this contemplation, because they attain unobstructed spiritual powers in all worlds.
There is a verse on this:
Sentient beings pervade the realm, endowed with hindrances and lacking causes,
The two kinds of definite turning, the buddhas have no mastery.
Second, the TathÄgata's body always abides. One should cultivate this mindfulness, because suchness is uninterrupted and liberated from defilements.
Third, the TathÄgata is most victorious and without fault. One should cultivate this mindfulness, because he is completely free from all afflictions and the hindrances to that which is to be known.
Fourth, the TathÄgata is without effort. One should cultivate this mindfulness, because without making effort, all buddha-works are uninterrupted.
Fifth, the TathÄgata experiences great bliss. One should cultivate this mindfulness, because his pure buddha-land is of great bliss.
Sixth, the TathÄgata is free from all defilements. One should cultivate this mindfulness, because although born in the world, all worldly dharmas cannot defile him.

Seventh, the TathÄgata is able to accomplish great matters. One should cultivate this mindfulness, manifesting perfect enlightenment, parinirvÄá¹‡a, and so forth. For all sentient beings who are not yet mature, he enables them to mature, and for those who are already mature, he enables them to attain liberation.
Here there are two verses:
Complete, belonging to one's own mind, endowed with permanence and purity,
Without effort, able to bestow the great Dharma joy of sentient beings,
Acting everywhere without dependence, equally benefiting many beings,
All buddhas, the wise, should cultivate mindfulness of all.
The commentary says:
This shows the bodhisattva cultivating mindfulness of the merits of the Dharma body of all buddhas.
Turning freely in all dharmas means that all tathÄgatas, due to thorough cultivation, attain free turning. Merely giving rise to the desire, all merits are able to be fully perfected and manifest.
If the tathÄgatas are unimpeded in their spiritual powers throughout all the immeasurable and limitless worlds, why is it that all sentient beings do not attain parinirvÄá¹‡a?
Because they have obstacles and lack causes.

The previous general explanation of the Buddha's attainment of mastery over all dharmas is now specifically revealed, showing that the Buddha does not have mastery over sentient beings. Therefore, the gÄthÄ is spoken.

Those in the realm of sentient beings who are all-encompassing, have obstacles, and lack causes, are called those who have obstacles because they have the obstacles of afflictions, karma, and retribution. The intense afflictions, the uninterrupted karmas, and the stupidity and dullness are in order.
Lacking the cause of nirvÄá¹‡a, lacking the spiritual lineage, is called lacking causes.
The two kinds of definite transformations refer to the definiteness of creating grave karma and the definiteness of experiencing retribution.

The definiteness of creating grave karma means repeatedly cultivating to make the homogeneous causes and the corresponding effects continue in a definite way, like AjÄtaÅ›atru who harmed his father, the king, and so on.

As for the definite retribution of feeling, this refers to the definite retribution of karma, and one definitely experiences the fruits of retribution. For example, the ÅšÄkyas were definitely to be killed by King VirÅ«á¸haka.
The Buddhas have no mastery over the above sentient beings to enable them to attain nirvÄá¹‡a.
Therefore, although it was said above that the TathÄgata has mastery over all dharmas, now it must be specifically stated that he does not have mastery.
As for the TathÄgata's eternal abiding, it is because the most pure suchness is his essence, because there is no change, and because there is no alteration.
As for the TathÄgata's supreme and sinless state, it is because he has eternally eliminated the sins of the afflictions and the obstacle to that which is to be known.
As for the TathÄgata's effortless state, it is like a heavenly musical instrument, the meaning of which is easy to understand.
As for the TathÄgata's experience of great bliss, it is because he experiences the great bliss of the Dharma, the adornments of the merit and virtue of the vast pure buddha lands.
As for the TathÄgata being free from defilements, it is like a red lotus flower, the meaning is easy to understand.

As for the TathÄgata being able to accomplish great matters, it means manifesting perfect enlightenment, parinirvÄá¹‡a, and so forth, accomplishing the vast benefits of sentient beings, causing them to mature and attain liberation according to their abilities.
These seven kinds of mindfulness of the Buddha cultivated are summarized in two verses.
The word perfect is used throughout.
As for belonging to the perfection of one's own mind, this includes the first characteristic of freely turning the wheel of the Dharma.
As for being endowed with the perfection of permanence, this includes the second characteristic of the permanence of the body.
As for being endowed with the perfection of purity, this includes the third characteristic of being supreme and faultless.
As for the perfection of effortless activity, this includes the fourth characteristic of effortless activity.
As for being able to bestow the perfection of great Dharma joy upon sentient beings, this includes the fifth characteristic of great Dharma joy.
The perfection of being unattached to all dharmas is the sixth characteristic, which means that all worldly dharmas cannot defile it.
The perfection of benefiting many beings equally is the seventh characteristic, which means that it can accomplish great matters and bring about vast benefits and happiness.
All buddhas refers to the perfect merits of all tathÄgatas.
Those with wisdom refers to great bodhisattvas.
Should cultivate all mindfulness means they should cultivate these seven kinds of mindfulness.
To remember, keep in mind, and not forget is the meaning of mindfulness.

As for enjoying such a pure buddha land that is exclusively pure and wonderful, it is because there is nothing impure, and because it is free from filth.
As for exclusively blissful, it is because there is no suffering or neutral feeling.

The treatise says:
Next, one should know that this suchness of the buddhas is able to perform five actions at all times:
First, its action is to save all beings from misfortune, because it can save the blind, deaf, insane, and others from misfortune merely by being seen.
Second, its action is to save from evil destinies, because it pulls beings out of unwholesome states and places them in wholesome states.
Third, its action is to save from ineffective practices, because it causes non-Buddhists to abandon ineffective practices seeking liberation and places them within the teachings of the TathÄgata.
Fourth, its activity is that of saving from the suffering of the triple world, because it bestows the path that transcends the triple world.

Fifth, its activity is that of saving from the vehicle, because it rescues bodhisattvas and those of indeterminate spiritual gene who are inclined toward other vehicles and causes them to cultivate the practices of the Great Vehicle.
It should be understood that the activities of all buddhas are equal in these five activities.
There is a verse on this:
Because of differences in cause, support, object, nature, and practice, it is admitted that their activities are different,
But in the world, these differences of power do not exist, and therefore they are not guides.
The explanation is as follows:
It should be understood that the Dharma realm of buddhas, which is the Dharma body, always performs five activities.
The activity of saving from misfortune means that the suffering of anxiety caused by illness, etc., is called misfortune.
The one who saves from misfortune is able to save from misfortune by merely seeing him, as in the case of the blind, deaf, and insane. As a scripture says:
When they see the Buddha, the blind regain their sight, the deaf regain their hearing, and the insane regain their mindfulness, and so on.
Question:

Answer:ğŸ”½Those who see the Dharma body, by the power of the great vows of the past, fully realize the Dharma body, and in sequence give rise to the function of the transformation body. Because of this, the blind can regain their sight and so on.

By the power of the past accumulations, one realizes the Dharma body and spontaneously gives rise to function like a machine wheel. Using the end to return to the basis, it is said that one sees the Dharma body, but in reality one only sees the transformation.

As for the function of saving from evil destinies and so on, it is only called saving when one pulls out from an unwholesome state and places in a wholesome state, because if the cause does not exist, the effect also does not exist.
The words the function of saving from non-skillful means and so on are clearly expressed.
